comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Photograph taken between 1908 and 1917 (but more probably about 1910)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Coats and very long shadows - must have been winter, late June.

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content: One F cls tram escaped conversion - F393, which is preserved by STM at Loftus. The story goes that this tramcar was tucked away at the back of a depot & was forgotten. When it was found, the project to convert all the F cls to L cls was finished. Being an orphan, it was decided to use it as a driver training tram. Had this not have happened, the tram would have been scrapped and no longer hanging around till the 1950's.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/29029178@N03] An interesting story! However, surely record keeping was better than that back in the early 1900st! 

Nonetheless, it does make you ask , why didn't someone say 'Where's 393, haven't seen her for a while?'

I think  the F-class is my favourite ... and it's a great pity that we haven't a preserved G-set, Now they would have been interesting!

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] From memory I read something in a SPER (Sydney Tram Museum) newsletter that they had secured a NZ tram which is pretty much identical to the G cls. At the moment it is still in NZ. 

Just done some research on F393.

The car was transferred to the service stock register in 1910 as a driver instruction tram, and renumbered as 127s. As such it technically was no longer an F cls tram, so that is why it got missed, when all F cls trams were sent to Randwick Workshop for conversion between 1906 and 1914.

In continued in the role of Driver Instruction Tram till 1952.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/29029178@N03] Ah, that clears up the mystery of F-393! Sounds like the bureaucracy was really at work! I can hear a bureaucrat in the Railways Department now saying  "127s? - no, not an F, couldn't be, see here ... it's on the service register!" Great research Peter, thanks. 

Thank goodness, it was preserved! 

Again, from memory the Gs were "off the shelf', so in all likelihood the NZ cars would have been, as you say, almost identical.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: "Splashes" (see note) was a weekly illustrated magazine (cost 3 pence) published between April 1899 and October 1911 - library.sl.nsw.gov.au/search~S2?/tSplashes+Weekly/tsplash... So latest date 1911.
